occurrences.line_text: Forcibly driuen with contrarie tydes
Tydings of warre and worldly trouble tell?
Yet wished tydings none of him vnto her brought.
Of that old woman tydings he besought,
Or tydings of her knight of the Redcrosse.
Tydings of warre, and of aduentures new;
And saw the signes, that deadly tydings spake,
O welcome thou, that doest of death bring tydings trew.
Of tydings strange, and of aduentures rare:
To come, and goe with tydings from the hart,
The watchman wayting tydings glad to heare,
Those tydings were, as he did vnderstand,
The tydings straunge did him abashed make,
Tydings of one, that hath vnto me donne
Tydings thereof, and so them still debar'd.
Tydings hereof came to his mothers eare;
And heauy tydings heard, whereas she playd
Vnto the man, that of him tydings to her brings.
If any tract of him or tydings they mote trace.
To tell what tydings of faire Florimell became.
Gan first inquire of tydings farre abrode;
Who thereto answering, said; the tydings bad,
And of eachone he met, he tydings did inquere.
Or to them tydings tell, that mote their harts delight.
Mote I request you tydings of my loue,
But no where could her find, nor tydings of her heare.
When Scudamour those heauie tydings heard,
Where they might tydings get of her estate;
Of tydings, what did vnto him betide,
Whereof when tydings came vnto mine eare,
Tydings of all, which there had hapned on the land.
Gan to demaund of her some tydings good,
What time sad tydings of his balefull smart
To whom when tydings thereof came, he streight
By this came tydings to the Tyrants eare,
The heauy Mayd, to whom none tydings bore
Wayting what tydings of her folke became.
He sought the plaines; but could no tydings heare.
Whose heauy tydings now I haue to tell.
That he by them might certaine tydings weene
Their shining shieldes about their wrestes they tye,
And peoples harts with awfull terrour tye,
And her attaching, thought her hands to tye;
But rather how she mote him faster tye.
With which she vsed still to tye her fone;
Striuing to loose the knot, that fast him tyes,
As when two Tygers prickt with hungers rage,
With Beares and Tygers taking heauie part,
As when a Beare and Tygre being met
But rudely rag'd, and like a cruell Tygre far'd.
Vpon a Tygre swift and fierce he rode,
As when a Tygre and a Lionesse
But first the Tygre clawes thereon did lay;
Into a Tygre, and that Tygres scath
What Tygre, or what other saluage wight
Like to a Tygre that hath mist his pray,
Vnto his Tygres taile, and shot at him apace.
But certes was with milke of Wolues and Tygres fed.
The Lyons rore, the Tygres loudly bray,
Of Beares and Tygres, nor so saluage mynded,
Into a Tygre, and that Tygres scath
And some of Tygres, that did seeme to gren,
And Tygris fierce, whose streames of none may be withstood.
And to the Maydens sounding tymbrels sung
By this dispred, that was the tyme ordayned
Coles of contention and whot vengeance tynd.
Of warlike armes in her forthwith they tynd,
To quench the flames, which she had tyn'd before,
Firebrand of hell first tynd in Phlegeton,
With fell despight her cruell arrowes tynde
To seeke her out with labour, and long tyne,
Next these came Tyne, along whose stony bancke
Lamenting sore his sorowfull sad tyne,
With that he sighed deepe for inward tyne:
Of Scots and English both, that tyned on his strand.
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine,
Vnto the type of kingdomes title clymes.
Orthrus begotten by great Typhaon,
There did Typhaon with her company;
Cruell Typhaon, whose tempestuous rage
Typhoeus ioynts were stretched on a gin,
Her sire Typhoeus was, who mad through merth,
They were by law of that proud Tyrannesse
But by a Tyrannesse (he then replide,)
But did vsurpe with wrong and tyrannie
Thrall to that Gyants hatefull tyrannie:
When raging passion with fierce tyrannie
from Gyants tyrannie.
In feeble Ladies tyranning so sore;
That did amongst the troupes so tyrannize;
But he him selfe vppon th rich doth tyrannize.
And tyrannizeth in the bitter smarts
So tyrannizing, and oppressing all,
Subdeweth to his kingdome tyrannous:
T'obay a womans tyrannous direction,
They each at other tyrannously flew;
With cruell malice and strong tyranny:
And exercise most bitter tyranny
Them comfortlesse, through tyranny or might:
No guilt in you, but in the tyranny of loue.
To all which cruell tyranny they say,
With flesh of men, whom through fell tyranny
And there her selfe did hyde from his hard tyranny.
That pride doe not to tyranny you lift;
That his beheast they feared, as tyrans law,
From tyrans rage, and euer-dying dread,
Rather then of the tyrant to be caught:
The Tyrant selfe came forth with yelling bray,
The which that tyrant gathered had by wrong
A cruell Tyrant had presumpteouslie
Whom a strong tyrant did vniustly thrall,
Against that cruell Tyrant, which opprest
And is he vanquisht by his tyrant enemy?
Not by that Tyrant, his intended foe;
Like to the Thracian Tyrant, who they say
By a strong Tyrant, who inuaded has
But this fell Tyrant, through his tortious powre,
Then this bold Tyrant, of her widowhed
Whereof that Tyrant had her now depriued,
Whereof when newes was to that Tyrant brought,
When her that Tyrant did of Crowne depriue;
But by that Tyrant is in wretched thraldome bound.
Till that a Tyrant, which Grandtorto hight,
Great Gloriane, that Tyrant to fordoo,
Willing him wend vnto the Tyrant streight,
There wayting for the Tyrant, till it was farre day.
The tyrant thundred his thicke blowes so fast,
But still the tyrant sternely at him layd,
That Parents deare from tyrants powre deliuer might.
That from the Daniske Tyrants head shall rend
That headlesse tyrants tronke he reard from ground,
And monstrous tyrants with his club subdewed;
Tyrants that make men subiect to their law,
But they like tyrants, mercilesse the more,
So on a tree, before the Tyrants dore,
For ayde, against that cruell Tyrants theft,
What else they haue, is all the Tyrants fee;
Into the field their Tyrants Seneschall.
Fallen into that Tyrants hand and vsage bad.
By this came tydings to the Tyrants eare,
Glad to be quit from that proud Tyrants awe,
That Tyrants part, with close or open ayde,
For he the tyraunt, which her hath in ward
This Nymph, quite tyr'd with heat of scorching ayre,
Till that at length nigh tyrd with former chace,
Where being tyrde with trauell, and opprest
And on her head she wore a tyre of gold,
And feeble nature cloth'd with fleshly tyre,
Ne other tyre she on her head did weare,
Straunge was her tyre, and all her garment blew,
Strange was her tyre; for on her head a crowne
Thy selfe to see, and tyred limbs to rest,
His tyred armes for toylesome wearinesse,
Which, for my Muse her selfe now tyred has,
Ne ought was tyred with his endlesse toyles,
His tyreling iade he fiercely forth did push,
Her tyreling iade, was bent her to abuse;
In which were not rich tyres, nor garments gay,
At th'upper end there sate, yclad in red
Doe flourish now, they into dust shall vade.
Their vapour vaded, shew their golden gleames,
The vaile, which did his powrefull light empeach;
Tho whenas vailed was her loftie crest,
That hand or foot to stirre he stroue in vaine:
But his wast wordes returnd to him in vaine:
Ne let vaine feares procure your needlesse smart,
But when he saw his labour all was vaine,
But when he saw his threatning was but vaine,
Them both together laid, to ioy in vaine delight.
As her slow beast could make; but all in vaine:
Heard how in vaine Fradubio did lament,
Proud of such glory and aduancement vaine,
Thought all their glorie vaine in knightly vew,
Full of vaine follies, and new fanglenesse:
Him selfe estraunging from their ioyaunce vaine,
Ah Dame (quoth he) thou temptest me in vaine,
Proud wemen, vaine, forgetfull of their yoke:
The last vaine helpe of womens great distresse,
To teach them truth, which worshipt her in vaine,
But in vaine glorious frayes he litle did delight.
Vntill with loue reuokt from vaine affright,
In vaine he seekes that hauing cannot hold.
That suddein cold did runne through euery vaine,
Th'enchaunter vaine his errour should not rew:
Who haplesse, and eke hopelesse, all in vaine
And eke so faint in euery ioynt and vaine,
With foltring tong, and trembling euery vaine,
But trembling feare did feele in euery vaine;
But presently was voide and wholly vaine:
But all in vaine: for he has read his end
Themselues in vaine: for since that glauncing sight,
In vaine to mocke, or mockt in vaine to bee:
In vaine to mocke, or mockt in vaine to bee:
But all in vaine: no fort can be so strong,
Nine monethes I seeke in vaine yet ni'll that vow vnbind.
Into the hart, and searcheth euery vaine,
Which when as Vna saw, through euery vaine
Ne let vaine words bewitch thy manly hart,
And vaine assurance of mortality,
As for loose loues they are vaine, and vanish into nought.
But th'idle stroke yet backe recoyld in vaine,
His wearie pounces all in vaine doth spend,
Which when in vaine he tryde with struggeling.
And thrise in vaine to draw it did assay,
She saw not stirre, off-shaking vaine affright,
So diuersly themselues in vaine they fray;
In which was nothing riotous nor vaine?
Nor doen vndo; (for vowes may not be vaine)
This craftie messenger with letters vaine,
Which when he long awaited had in vaine,
Witnesse ye heaue[n]s, whom she in vaine to helpe did call.
But vaine: for ye shall dearely do him rew,
Vaine is the vaunt, and victory vniust,
Vaine Braggadocchio getting Guyons
A pleasing vaine of glory vaine did find,
A pleasing vaine of glory vaine did find,
In which vaine Braggadocchio was mewed,
Ne car'd he greatly for her presence vaine,
To menage steeds, as did this vaunter; but in vaine.
His force was vaine, and strooke more often wide,
And grimly gnash, threatning reuenge in vaine:
Vaine others ouerthrowes, who selfe doth ouerthrowe.
Ne would with vaine occasions be inflamed;
The vile Acrasia, that with vaine delightes,
And flowes in pleasures, and vaine pleasing toyes,
Calling thy helpe in vaine, that here in ioyes art dround.
To feede her foolish humour, and vaine iolliment.
For all her words she drownd with laughter vaine,
And other whiles vaine toyes she would deuize
Vaine man (said she) that wouldest be reckoned
With false delights, and fild with pleasures vaine,
Seeking for daunger and aduentures vaine?
And vaine delight she saw he light did pas,
And stroue in vaine, the one himselfe to drowne,
Sith late with him I batteil vaine would boste;
Mammon (said he) thy godheades vaunt is vaine,
Vaine glorious Elfe (said he) doest not thou weet,
With such vaine shewes thy worldlings vile abuse:
Sterne was his looke, and full of stomacke vaine,
With crownes and Diademes, & titles vaine,
The knight him seeing labour so in vaine,
So lost his labour vaine and idle industry.
Which he had brought for Braggadocchio vaine.
In vaine therefore, Pyrrochles, should I lend
Gaue signes of grudge and discontentment vaine:
Such life ye read, and vertue in vaine shew,
Through vaine illusion of their lust vnclene,
And fell to vaine voluptuous disease:
Vaine feasts, and idle superfluity:
A downe the streame, and all his vowes make vaine,
And thought his labour lost and trauell vaine,
Doth rore at them in vaine, and with great terror raue.
And all her vaine allurements did forsake,
Labour'd in vaine, to haue recur'd their prize,
And eke her louer stroue: but all in vaine;
Mote breede him scath vnwares: but all in vaine;
And with vaine thoughts her falsed fancy vex:
Which spent in vaine, at last she told her briefe,
Her selfe a while therein she vewd in vaine;
And euery trembling ioynt, and euery vaine
In vaine seekes wonders out of Magicke spell.
To doe away vaine doubt, and needlesse dreed:
With their light wings, the sights of semblants vaine:
But labour'd long in that deepe ford with vaine disease.
And rubd his temples, and each trembling vaine;
Of her vaine plaint, and to her scoffing sayd;
So fled faire Florimell from her vaine feare,
At last in vaine was forst to turne his flight,
But in vaine sheows, that wont yongknights bewitch,
But all my dayes am like to wast in vaine,
Enough to hold a foole in vaine delight:
Proud Braggadocchio, that in vaunting vaine
To such vaine vses, that him best became:
All that she might, and him in vaine reuild:
A long discourse of his aduentures vaine,
In vaine he feares that, which he cannot shonne:
But all in vaine; for nought mote him relent,
The powre thereof, and lou'd so oft in vaine,
Bransles, Ballads, virelayes, and verses vaine;
But all in vaine, his woman was too wise,
And with vaine hope his spirits faint supply,
And all that else the vaine world vaunten may,
Then all the world is lost, and we in vaine haue toyld.
But all in vaine: and then turnd to the heard,
Where he through priuy griefe, and horrour vaine,
And sow vaine sorrow in a fruitlesse eare,
For daunger vaine it were, to haue assayd
Vaine was the watch, and bootlesse all the ward,
As those same plumes, so seemd he vaine and light,
His garment was disguised very vaine,
It vaine she thought with rigorous vprore
In vaine she wisht, that fate n'ould let her yet possesse.
Then with vaine poemes weeds to haue their fancies fed.
Of thy vaine boast, and spoile of loue misgotten,
Of the bad issue of his counsell vaine,
With which vaine termes so much they did the[m]; moue,
And being dead in vaine yet many striue:
That stroue in vaine him long to haue withstood,
Most wretched men, whose dayes depend on thrids so vaine.
Therefore this Fay I hold but fond and vaine,
And maketh him his wing in vaine to spend;
Stand vp so long, and weapon vaine to weld,
Then life and labour both in vaine to spend.
At which his vaine excuse they all gan smile,
For glorie vaine their fellowship to lose,
That all men threw out vowes and wishes vaine.
But all in vaine: for what might one do more?
In vaine he sought; for there he found it not;
That many wish to win for glorie vaine,
Amongst the rest with boastfull vaine pretense
The cause and end thereof: but all in vaine;
So euery place seem'd painefull, and ech changing vaine.
A downe in vaine, ne harm'd her any more.
But when in vaine to fight she oft assayd,
Feared in vaine, sith meanes ye see there wants theretoo.
Vaine is the art that seekes it selfe for to deceiue.
That seekes to know anothers griefe in vaine,
At last when long he follow'd had in vaine,
And saw that all he said and did, was vaine,
But when as long he looked had in vaine,
And eke that age despysed nicenesse vaine,
With curses vaine in his auengefull ire:
Came to that Squire, yet trembling euery vaine:
To see his foe breath out his spright in vaine:
But ah she giuen is to vaine delight,
But all in vaine, her plaints might not preuaile,
On which this shield, of many sought in vaine,
And seeking often entraunce, afterwards in vaine.
Though vaine I see my sorrowes to vnfold,
But O vaine iudgement, and conditions vaine,
But O vaine iudgement, and conditions vaine,
Gainst womens loue, long giuen him in vaine.
But all in vaine: for why he found no way
And romed round about the rocke in vaine,
She gan a fresh to chafe, and grieue in euery vaine.
To Proteus selfe to sew she thought it vaine,
That hence so long departed, is but vaine:
In vaine loud crying, and into the flood
And cluster thicke vnto his leasings vaine,
In vaine therefore doest thou now take in hand,
But vaine it was to thinke from him to flie.
For vaine it is to deeme of things aright,
Of their vaine prowesse, turned to their proper bale.
With indignation, at her vaunting vaine,
Doth beat vpon the gentle bird in vaine,
At last when long she struggled had in vaine,
Scorning her offers and conditions vaine;
Many vaine fancies, working her vnrest;
Forcing in vaine the rest to her to tell,
Her selfe there close afflicted long in vaine,
She saw it vaine to make there lenger stay,
And her late vile reproch, though vaunted vaine,
Which vaine conceipt now nourishing no more,
In vaine the Pagan bannes, and sweares, and rayles,
Crying to them in vaine, that nould his crying heare.
Crying in vaine for helpe, when helpe was past.
And both with hope of shadowes vaine inspyred.)
Stryuing long time in vaine it to withstond;
It would no passage yeeld vnto his purpose vaine.
And of his owne vaine fancies thought did frame:
To him for aide, who long in vaine their rage withstands.
But all in vaine, their numbers are so great,
Gainst whom my selfe I long in vaine haue bent,
In vaine he seeketh others to suppresse,
Weeping to him in vaine, and making piteous woe.
Fellow of this I beare, throwne not in vaine,
In vaine complayning, to be so abused.
But all in vaine; for why, no remedy
His violence in vaine, and with his spere
And euery way did try, but all in vaine:
But when the Saluage saw his labour vaine,
Stryuing in vaine that nigh his bowels brast,
Gnashing his cruell teeth at him in vaine,
For which he long in vaine did sweat and swinke,
And seuerall deceipts, but all in vaine:
In vaine of me ye hope for remedie,
And I likewise in vaine doe salues to you applie.
Contagious poyson close through euery vaine,
In vaine therefore it were, with medicine
Crying in vaine to her, him to bemone;
Began to tremble euery limbe and vaine;
From natiue home, and spent my youth in vaine,
Be but vaine shadowes to this safe retyre
In vaine (said then old Meliboe) doe men
And many gealous thoughts conceiu'd in vaine,
Rather then hunt still after shadowes vaine
The woods did nought but ecchoes vaine rebound;
And bet abacke, threatning in vaine to bite,
Striuing in vaine to rere him selfe vpright.
After that he had labourd long in vaine,
Vaine-glorious man, when fluttring wind does blow
Leasings, backbytings, and vaine-glorious crakes,
Through vainely crossed shield he quite did pierce,
Did flie abacke, and made him vainely swinke:
The which his mother vainely did expound,
That they auoyded were, and vainely by did slyde.
Who shortly must repent that now so vainely brauest.
So all that day in wandring vainely he did spend.
There I beheld such vainenesse, as I neuer thought.
And scorching Sunne does dry my secret vaines:
Thought to haue mounted, but his feeble vaines
But Blandamour full of vainglorious spright,
With timely pride aboue the Aegyptian vale,
She wandred many a wood, and measurd many a vale.
His weary wagon to the Westerne vale,
Did seeme to ouerlooke the lowly vale;
As he is wont at each Saint Valentide,
Stone more of valew, and more smooth and fine,
Of passing valew, and of great renowme,
Which when the valiant Elfe perceiu'd, he lept
And valiant knight become a caytiue thrall,
Which well that valiant courser did discerne;
Yet since he seemed valiant, through vnknowne,
There where he saw the valiant Triamond
Who well was knowen to be a valiant Knight,
And therein wonned twenty valiant Knights;
And valiant hearts, in thoughts lesse hard and bold,
Sixe valiant Knights, of one faire Nymphe yborne,
And valiant knights doe rashly enterprize,
To let him weet his doughtie valiaunce,
Life will I graunt thee for thy valiaunce,
Whom gracious lot, and thy great valiaunce
He ouerthrew through his owne valiaunce;
Where also proofe of thy prow valiaunce
Aswell for glory of great valiaunce,
Straunge sort of fight, three valiaunt knights to see
Shall backe repulse the valiaunt Brockwell twise,
Ill seemes (sayd he) if he so valiaunt be,
His dwelling is low in a valley greene,
As mountaine doth the valley ouercast.
The valley did with coole shade ouercast,
And mighty woods, which did the valley shade,
A little valley, subiect to the same,
And euery wood, and euery valley wyde
Through all the fields and vallies did before him flie.
Which vnto things of valorous pretence
Ye warlike payre, whose valorous great might
But gathering force, and courage valorous,
And cruell rancour dim'd his valorous
Fiercely aduaunst his valorous right arme,
Bards tell of many women valorous
Of life: for he was nothing valorous,
His whole exploite, and valorous emprize,
Whom not my valour, but his owne braue mind
Yet full of valour, the which did adorne
And him with equall value counteruayld:
Then vertues might, and values confidence,
As for loose loues they are vaine, and vanish into nought.
Ne into ayre did vanish presently,
Was suddein vanished out of his sight:
The glorious picture vanisheth away,
But vanisht is. The Elfe him cals alowd,
Was vanisht quite, and of that monstrous mas
That vanisht into smoke and cloudes swift;
His painted nimble wings, and vanisht quite away.
For soone as he was vanisht out of sight,
But lo, they streight were vanisht all and some,
Now vanisht vtterly, and cleane subuerst
Was vanisht quite, as it were not the same,
Th'enchaunted Damzell vanisht into nought:
The vanisht all away out of his sight,
A gentle Husher, Vanitie by name
Mine eyes no more on vanitie shall feed,
The plumes of pride, and wings of vanitie,
Was lightnesse seene, or looser vanitie,
That puffed vp with smoke of vanitie,
And though he scornd his idle vanitie,
And blow the bellowes to his swelling vanity.
But him the Palmer from that vanity,
For want whereof he weighed vanity,
And that which wont to vanquish God and man,
To vanquish all the world with matchlesse might,
And so will I, if me he vanquish may,
Doth vanquish Crudor, and doth make
That if I vanquishe him, he shall obay
Who hauing oft in battell vanquished
And yet the vanquished had no despight:
Ne was he euer vanquished afore,
And vanquished all ventrous knights in fight;
Were vanquished, and put to foule disgrace,
Who see your vanquisht foes before you lye:
Enough is, that thy foe doth vanquisht stand
But vanquisht thine eternall bondslaue make,
Bought with the bloud of vanquisht Paynim bold:
And vanquisht them, vnable to withstand:
In which him vanquisht she to fly constraind:
And left inglorious on the vanquisht playne,
Then he halfe vanquisht, then the other seemed,
But euer vanquisht all, with whom he fought;
And is he vanquisht by his tyrant enemy?
And taking with him, as his vanquisht thrall,
For needlesse feare did neuer vantage none,
To ketch him at a vantage in his snares.
Who making vantage of their ciuill iarre,
With his dull vapour all that desert has,
Vpblowing, doth disperse the vapour lo'st,
A litle smoke, whose vapour thin and light,
Their vapour vaded, shew their golden gleames,
Now gan the humid vapour shed the ground
In deawy vapours of the westerne maine,
